title: 107_s1614
content: The Act may be cited as the "Historically Women's Public Colleges and Universities Historic Building Preservation and Restoration Act". It includes definitions for key terms. The Act, titled "Historically Women's Public Colleges and Universities Historic Building Preservation and Restoration Act," defines key terms such as historically women's public college or university and historic building or structure. The former refers to public higher education institutions established in the US between 1836 and 1908 for women's industrial education, including specific listed institutions. The latter pertains to buildings or structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places or designated as national historic landmarks. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. Preservation and restoration grants for historic buildings and structures at historically women's public colleges and universities. The Secretary will award grants to historically women's public colleges and universities for the preservation and restoration of historic buildings. Grantees must agree to certain conditions, including obtaining Secretary's approval for alterations and allowing public access for interpretive and educational purposes. The Federal share of the cost of a grant for preservation or restoration of a historic building or structure is 50 percent, while the non-Federal share can be provided in cash or in-kind goods or services. $16,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2006 to carry out this act. For fiscal year 2002, $2,000,000 from the amounts available will be used to grant historically women's public colleges and universities in various states. For fiscal year 2002, funds will be allocated to historically women's public colleges and universities in different states, such as Oklahoma, South Carolina, and Texas. If less than $16,000,000 is available, each institution will receive a portion of the total amount. In the following years, a fraction of the total amount will be distributed to the grantees specified. The Secretary will establish regulations for this process. The Secretary will promulgate regulations necessary to implement the Act.
